items.title: Murder trial resumes for Ontario couple who’d been trying to adopt 12-year-old boy who died
Inflation ticks up to 2.4% in December as last year's GST break impacts data
items.summary_auto: Canada's inflation rate ticked up to 2.4 per cent in December compared to the same period last year, when the federal government implemented a GST break that brought some prices down, Statistics Canada said on Monday.

items.title: Ottawa, Vancouver shake up rosters with PWHL-record 6-player swap
items.summary_auto: The Ottawa Charge and the PWHL expansion Vancouver Goldeneyes shook up their rosters by completing a six-player trade on Sunday night.

items.title: At least 19 killed, dozens missing in massive Karachi mall fire
items.summary_auto: Pakistani firefighters began pulling bodies from the smoldering remains of a sprawling Karachi shopping mall on Monday, where more than 60 people were still missing after a massive fire that killed at least 19 people.

items.title: Faculty on strike at Laurentian University, classes temporarily cancelled
items.summary_auto: Faculty, academic librarians and counsellors represented by the Laurentian University Faculty Association (LUFA) in Sudbury, Ont. are on strike.

items.title: Growing lineups mix with affordability challenges as Winnipeg retailers navigate surge in gold prices
items.summary_auto: With the steady surge in the price of gold, more customers are lining up to sell off or invest in the precious metal at some Winnipeg retailers, as those businesses are also wrestling with alternatives to make the karats more attainable.

items.title: Thousands without power, schools closed as winter storm hits N.S.
items.summary_auto: More than 100,000 homes and businesses in Nova Scotia have lost power, and public schools are closed as a winter storm brings wet and heavy snow to the province.

items.title: New health warnings considered a good start, but do they go far enough?
items.summary_auto: Canada Health’s new front-of-package labelling is giving consumers more nutritional information at a glance. A magnifying-glass graphic is now mandatory to alert shoppers about foods high in saturated fat, sugar or sodium.

items.title: Young man at centre of N.L. sexual abuse investigation died after testifying
items.summary_auto: The young man who was the catalyst for a police investigation into accused sexual predators Tony Humby and Bruce Escott has died. His mother is remembering him as a gentle soul who put his life on the line in pursuit of justice.

items.title: How Canadian doctors are preparing for potential FIFA World Cup public health challenges
Uber called out by service dog users who are fed up with ride rejections
Quebec says police need power to randomly stop people. Can it convince Supreme Court?
items.summary_auto: Should a police officer be able to pull you over without a reason? The Supreme Court is hearing arguments on a Quebec case that deals with exactly that. Proponents of random police traffic stops say they're important to stop drunk drivers. Detractors say they open the door to racial profiling.

items.title: Sexual assault survivor calls for accountability after police comments left her feeling ‘humiliated’
items.summary_auto: An Ontario woman who regularly shared her experiences as a sexual assault survivor at police training courses says she’s ending her relationship with the Ontario Police College and is raising concerns about what she and several experts say are harmful biases among some officers and a lack of accountability from the college.

items.title: Can ICE be restrained?
items.summary_auto: Anti-ICE protests continued throughout Minnesota over the weekend, as they have for nearly two weeks now. Since the shooting of Renee Good in Minneapolis, ICE agents have been getting in confrontations with the people they are targeting, and the citizens attempting to observe and document ICE’s actions. The city and state are on a razor’s edge — trying to observe and protest while not giving U.S. President Donald Trump an opportunity to escalate.

items.title: With Legault out and the CAQ reeling, here's where Quebec's parties stand
items.summary_auto: Quebec's political landscape is in flux following Premier François Legault's surprise resignation last week after more than seven years in power.

items.title: Canada's co-hosting the FIFA World Cup — and preparing for a potential surge in health emergencies. Here's how
items.summary_auto: As Toronto and Vancouver gear up to co-host FIFA World Cup games this summer, an emergency doctor worries that Canada’s overburdened health-care system won’t be able to handle the extra demand from possible infectious disease outbreaks or weather-related illnesses.

items.title: How a Toronto mural changed Ian Williams’s book title
items.summary_auto: The Toronto-based writer and past Giller Prize winner spoke with Mattea Roach about his latest novel, You've Changed.

items.title: Man dead after police-involved shooting on New Brunswick First Nation
items.summary_auto: An independent police watchdog agency is investigating a fatal "police-involved shooting" that occurred in Neqotkuk First Nation, formerly known as Tobique, in northwestern New Brunswick, Sunday evening.

items.title: Vancouver police deployed to 11 planned protests in 1 weekend
items.summary_auto: It was a weekend of demonstrations in Vancouver with at least 11 protests happening across the city, drawing thousands of people and extra police officers.

items.title: #TheMoment Kawhi Leonard joined kids on the basketball court
items.summary_auto: Martha Ramos tells the National about the moment former Toronto Raptors star Kawhi Leonard joined a group of local kids to play basketball on a new court in Scarborough, Ont.

items.title: Death toll climbs to 39 in high-speed train collision in Spain
items.summary_auto: Spanish police said Monday that at least 39 people are confirmed dead in a high-speed train collision the previous night in the south of the country, and rescue efforts were continuing.

items.title: Wildfires in Chile kill at least 18: authorities
items.summary_auto: Wildfires raging across central and southern Chile on Sunday left at least 18 people dead, scorched thousands of acres of forest and destroyed hundreds of homes, authorities said, as the South American country swelters under a heat wave.

items.title: Carney weighs sending soldiers to Greenland for military exercises with NATO allies: sources
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney is considering sending soldiers to Greenland for military exercises with NATO allies, as U.S. President Donald Trump threatens tariffs on European nations unless they let him purchase and control the semiautonomous island, two senior Canadian officials told CBC News.

items.title: Lululemon's next CEO will need to refine and innovate: experts
items.summary_auto: In the last two years, Lululemon's rivals have upped their game, while the Vancouver-based retailer has been criticized for a lack of new styles, had to remove a leggings line that failed with customers, and saw its stock tumble by almost 60 per cent.

items.title: Trump's 'Board of Peace' proposal met with skepticism, caution amid shaky Gaza ceasefire
items.summary_auto: The two-year war in Gaza between Israel and Hamas eased with a ceasefire three months ago, but there has been neither peace nor reconstruction. Phase 2 promises progress, but the peace process itself is becoming increasingly controversial.
